head.title: Ward, Hayes And Johnson Get Jet Pacts

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/Sports/Pro Football/National Football League/New York Jets

hedline.hl1: Ward, Hayes And Johnson Get Jet Pacts

abstract.p: New York Jets re-sign receiver Dedric Ward, running back Leon Johnson and special teams player Chris Hayes to one year contracts (S)

block.p: The Jets may still have plans to acquire a high-profile, veteran free-agent wide receiver, like Cincinnati's Carl Pickens, but yesterday, they made the expected move, awarding Dedric Ward a new, one-year contract. The team also signed running back Leon Johnson and the special teams player Chris Hayes to one-year contracts. Cornerback Tony Scott, the Jets' sixth-round pick from North Carolina State, signed a two-year deal.

The Jets may still have plans to acquire a high-profile, veteran free-agent wide receiver, like Cincinnati's Carl Pickens, but yesterday, they made the expected move, awarding Dedric Ward a new, one-year contract. The team also signed running back Leon Johnson and the special teams player Chris Hayes to one-year contracts. Cornerback Tony Scott, the Jets' sixth-round pick from North Carolina State, signed a two-year deal.

Ward, entering his fourth year, was a restricted free agent with little negotiating leverage and had been tendered a $472,000 contract for next season by the Jets. During the recently concluded restricted free-agent signing period, Ward did not draw a significant offer from another team. His new deal with the Jets is also for $472,000, but includes incentives Ward can earn with a stellar season, and is keyed to the Jets' winning the majority of their games. People familiar with the contract said the Jets also suggested that they would consider giving Ward a long-term deal later this year if Ward's numbers improved dramatically during the 2000 season.

Last season, Ward had 22 receptions for 325 yards and 3 touchdowns. He also returned 38 punts for an average of 7.6 yards. Ward, 25, has 63 career catches for 1,014 yards. For now, the Jets' starting receivers are Ward, who is 5 feet 9 inches and 180 pounds, and Wayne Chrebet, who is officially listed as being 5-10 and weighing 188 pounds. The team drafted wide receiver Laveranues Coles in the third round and used its fifth-round pick to draft another receiver, Windrell Hayes. Both had impressive rookie minicamps.

Still, the Jets would appear to be in the market for Pickens, who is wearing out his welcome in Cincinnati, or possibly Andre Hastings, a free agent who last played in New Orleans. The question is whether the Jets can afford Pickens, whose price tag might be in the $3 million range.
Johnson, 25, was another restricted free agent and he also received an incentive-laden contract.
